Input.threadtitle: Falling balls - Part 1 - Question about weight
Input.posts:
I'm not sure if I should be spelling out the answer options, or even the question, in that video (though maybe it wouldn't matter for these in-video questions), but aren't two of those answers potentially correct? If I use the example of the biscuits with both weight and mass printed on them, those biscuits' weight hasn't being measured 'when nothing is touching them', has it? I'm not even sure how to pose the question, especially without giving away spoilers... :-(
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
There is a long thread about weight and what a scale measures at: https://class.coursera.org/howthingswork1-002/forum/thread?thread_id=78 A short answer to your question about biscuits and their labeling: The mass of a packet of biscuits has nothing to do with gravity. You measure that mass by exerting a known force on the biscuits and observing how they accelerate. The weight of a packet of biscuits is the force exerted on those biscuits by gravity (usually Earth's gravity, unless you go on a really big trip). Measuring that force is difficult, because it is exert on the biscuits themselves. So a scale has to make an indirect measurement. That's discussed in the thread above. Lou

Instructor's Post
Friction is results from microscopic interactions between two surfaces that are touching. At a simplistic level, you can think of those surfaces as microscopically rough, at least at the atomic scale. As a result, those surfaces can exert forces on one another that either prevent or impede sliding motion. Think of two hairbrushes or egg crates pressed against one another. They'll have difficult sliding across one another because their microscopic projections collide or push on one another as they slide or try to slide. At a more sophisticated level, the two surfaces form various types of chemical and physical bonds with one another and consequently have trouble sliding. Lou

Input.posts:
Hello,\xA0 in Part 5 Skater, we hear about friction. What exactly is it? 2. If i push a book forward, why it is stop? Because the Gravitiy Force are stronger that the Force of this previos push?
Upvotes:

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Friction is results from microscopic interactions between two surfaces that are touching. At a simplistic level, you can think of those surfaces as microscopically rough, at least at the atomic scale. As a result, those surfaces can exert forces on one another that either prevent or impede sliding motion. Think of two hairbrushes or egg crates pressed against one another. They'll have difficult sliding across one another because their microscopic projections collide or push on one another as they slide or try to slide. At a more sophisticated level, the two surfaces form various types of chemical and physical bonds with one another and consequently have trouble sliding. Lou
